We provide a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is based on a small number of axioms that are easily verifiable. The axioms are shown to be sufficient to guarantee that the category of linear operators on a Hilbert space is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions on a Hilbert space. This is a significant result because it provides a mathematical foundation for the reconstruction programs of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been the subject of intense study for over a century. Despite this, the origin of the group remains elusive. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related species of myxozoans. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is remarkably reduced, with a small genome and a large number of genes lost. These results suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by extreme degeneration of the genome and gene content. This study provides insight into the molecular basis of the evolution of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The disease is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear import of key transcription factors. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of transcription factors. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to disrupt nuclear import. Our data uncover a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings have important implications for the development of antiviral strategies against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Voltage-gated proton channels are important for many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. Meeting the food demand of this population will be challenging because of the expected increase in global mean temperature. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. (Show more)

The coexistence of species in complex communities is a fundamental problem in ecology. Niche partitioning is one mechanism that can promote coexistence, but it is difficult to test empirically because of the high costs of species-level identification. We used DNA metabarcoding to identify plant species consumed by seven species of large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree of diet overlap was strongly correlated with the proportion of grass consumption, suggesting that the proportion of grass consumption can be used to infer diet breadth. We also found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that the coexistence of species in LMH assemblages may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the drivers of biodiversity in complex communities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020. The survey asked about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on business operations and finances. We find that many small businesses are financially fragile. Moreover, the majority of businesses plan to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean interior. These sinks are likely to be a combination of nano-fragmentation of the plastic debris, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The origin of presolar silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This study provides new insights into the origin of presolar silicon carbide grains. It also provides constraints for the formation of the Solar System. This article is protected by copyright. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950. The expansion has been driven by the motorized fleet, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous, but it contributes only a quarter of the global engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, but there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years. The global fleet is expected to grow by a million more vessels by midcentury, which will challenge the sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all species. In this study, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also a highly conserved trait. We find that the ability to produce offspring is strongly correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is not only from the mother’s own metabolism but also from the energy available to the mother from the environment.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-synuclein in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-synuclein, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA. This would be the first treatment for MSA. This study opens the door to the development of VX-765 as a treatment for MSA. This would be the first treatment for MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels. It is the first line of defense against pathogens and the main interface between the blood and the tissues. It is also the main regulator of blood vessel function. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control its function in response to the environment. This paper describes the nature of the communication system between endothelial cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data API that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for research and public health purposes.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are responsible for the generation and propagation of the cardiac and neuronal action potentials. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for K+ ions. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the functional and structural coupling between the selectivity filter and the activation gate. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural switch for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the selectivity filter and the activation gate. It also provides a structural mechanism for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is influenced by the host and the host environment. The anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gut are a largely unexplored group of microbes that may play a role in the health of the host. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products that could be used as therapeutics. This work also provides a resource for the discovery of novel natural products. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes an individual to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is due to a low probability to become dominant. These findings have important implications for understanding the role of anxiety in social behavior and for the development of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our study also highlights the importance of mitochondrial function in the brain for social behavior. This is the first study to show that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and points to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture structures with desired mechanical responses is critical for the development of functional devices. However, the design of such structures is often limited by the availability of materials and the lack of a systematic approach. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the optimal synthesis of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are then assembled into architectures to achieve highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design and manufacture function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of programmable structures.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans. The hemoglobin levels in the blood are regulated by the expression of the globin genes. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is expressed in the erythroid lineage, can affect the expression of the globin genes. This effect is mediated by the IGF2BP1 protein, which can bind to the globin mRNAs and affect their stability. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the hemoglobin levels in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Conversely, ectopic expression of SREPB1 or SCD1 restored ferroptosis resistance in these cells, even when mTORC1 was inhibited.

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with heart failure in elderly patients. We show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving STIM1 and ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of these drugs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanism for the association of these drugs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral ecosystems, but not in older forests. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forest–associated bird populations, and the policy’s effects on older forests have been slow to appear. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a model for policy that integrates monitoring and adaptive management. We hope that our findings will contribute to the ongoing evaluation of this policy. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a computational approach to design new acylide antibiotics. We show that the design strategy is successful in terms of in vitro activity and in vivo efficacy. The best designed compounds are up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, the current standard of care. The design strategy can be used to develop new acylide antibiotics with improved properties. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new architecture for deep convolutional neural networks. The architecture is based on the use of dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The architecture is easy to implement and train, and can be used in a wide range of problems. The architecture is also easy to extend to other problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. From

The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the impact of such devices on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delights the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces sleepiness. These effects are likely to be mediated by the light emitted by the device. The results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (Show more)

The Younger Dryas (YD) chronozone marks a period of global climate change. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YD boundary. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YD sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Os isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YD sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YD site in Pennsylvania indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YD cooling. (Show more)

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation. However, its role in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the lung, gut, and salivary glands. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We show that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of angiosperms, and that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of plant-feeding insects, including the origin of leaf miners and wood borers. Our results also suggest that the evolution of herbivory in insects may be driven by multiple factors, including the evolution of efficient microbial symbionts and the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of herbivory in insects. © 2016, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as T cell receptors and enzymes. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also a major protein in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that participates in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we show that APOE isoform is highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also show that APOE4 is associated with increased accumulation of complement protein C1q in the brain, which may contribute to APOE4-associated AD risk. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, and they suggest that APOE4-associated AD risk may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes. They also suggest the possibility that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.08 g/cm3, which is 13 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed by the rapid solidification of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. This study provides a new perspective on the inner core formation by revealing the nucleation mechanism of the inner core. This study also provides a clue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This work is expected to contribute to the understanding of the Earth. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is widely used, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are unknown. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in brain DA responses to methylphenidate, which are associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human skill. It is therefore of great interest to understand how the human brain processes language. We developed a methodology that allows us to systematically compare the processing of language in the human brain with the processing of language in neural networks. We find that the most powerful models of language processing in the brain are also the most powerful models of language processing in the world. These results provide computational evidence for the role of predictive processing in the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that we may be able to use machine learning to improve the speed and accuracy of brain-based language therapies.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is not clear whether it is stable, i.e., whether it can be made to converge to a unique solution. We show that this is not the case. We also introduce a new algorithm that is stable and fast.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a failure of communication. This is a convenient way of blaming people for not understanding the exponential growth of the pandemic. However, the evidence for this claim is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. It is discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably conserved and that they are still able to cause disease. This study provides a foundation for future studies of the biology of these two leprosy-causing bacteria. (Read more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nonlinear problem, which has resisted a complete analytical treatment so far. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of interacting systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only currently available vaccine is based on the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. However, the spike protein is a large protein that is difficult to express in a safe and effective manner. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a segment of the spike protein that was codon-pair deoptimized to reduce the number of potential translation errors. This vaccine candidate is easy to express and is highly protective in animal models. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and mortality. It is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and can spread by multiple transmission pathways. Today, plague is almost exclusively spread by fleas, but this is a relatively recent phenomenon. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by human fleas fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by fleas during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model fitting. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of different species have different shapes and sizes. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of cognitive ability. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of cognitive ability.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. Actin filaments are the building blocks of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is critical for many cellular processes, including cell motility. In this study, we show that the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) binds to actin filaments and disassembles them. We show that the binding of ADF to actin filaments is enhanced by the curvature of the filament and by the torque applied to the filament by the cell. These findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF in cell motility.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for the development of obesity and suggest that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than previously thought. They also highlight the importance of considering the type of carbohydrate consumed in the context of overall energy intake. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East, suggesting a recent arrival of the Malagasy people. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 800,000 people in the study. The results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook, and that this is a form of emotional contagion. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media, and for our understanding of the mechanisms of emotional contagion. They also suggest that the study of emotional contagion should be extended to social media.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequence is modified in many ways, including the addition of chemical groups to the RNA backbone. One of the most common modifications is the pseudouridine (Ψ) moiety, which is found in the coding regions of mRNAs. We show that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis and the decoding of mRNA codons. These findings have implications for understanding the function of Ψ moieties in the human transcriptome. They also suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ moieties in the mRNA sequence and that this can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. Our work provides insight into the role of Ψ moieties in the human transcriptome. (Show more)

This study shows that the subjective feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This feeling may be a key to human flourishing and longevity.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in biology. However, the drivers of this pattern remain unclear. Here, we use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is confined to a narrow range of body sizes. This model provides a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is likely to continue in the future.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is used to promote long-term attachment to surfaces, which is critical for the pathogen to establish infections. The type IV pili are extended and retracted, and this activity is sensed by a chemosensory system that regulates the activity of the pili. This system is similar to the chemotaxis system used by many bacteria to sense gradients of chemical signals. Our results demonstrate that the type IV pili are mechanosensitive and can be used as a sensor to regulate surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanism is likely to be used by other bacteria to sense surfaces and may be important for the establishment of infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is responsible for millions of deaths. Deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and experimentally infected fawns can transmit the virus. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in 33% of free-living deer in Iowa. We also show that the number of deer-to-deer transmissions is likely much higher than previously estimated. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the disease is still debated. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in the brain, even in the absence of Aβ plaques. This neuron-derived inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. Thus, we propose that Aβ is not the only factor that triggers the AD-related immune response. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. © 2016 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for its use for economic purposes is, however, still unknown. We present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study contributes to the understanding of the role of the domestic chicken in the development of the human economy. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process. It is important to understand the steps that the protein must take to reach the native state. This study shows that the folding of a large protein is more complex than previously thought.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be critical for the function of those molecules as precursors to RNA caps. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 accumulation. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. We show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, can restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and the system’s activity or “pace” of change is self-regulating. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, where the system’s activity is maximal. The critical state is stable, and the system returns to the critical state after a perturbation. The critical state is maintained by the system’s dynamics, and the system’s activity is anticorrelated with external stimuli. SOC systems are ubiquitous in nature and in physics. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, it is not easy to tune its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized by applying strain. This opens up opportunities to tailor its properties.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in animals has led to the development of a new class of antibiotics. However, the discovery of such peptides in plants is still in its infancy. Here, we report the discovery of a plant antifungal peptide, NCR044, which is highly effective against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and it was found to be highly dynamic and largely disordered. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens, and it bound to bioactive phosphoinositides. The peptide was effective in controlling gray mold disease in tomato and tobacco plants. This work illustrates the potential of plant antifungal peptides as a new class of fungistats/fungicides. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions support the viability of sperm during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of sperm during the posttesticular period and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. These findings have implications for understanding the molecular basis of reproductive success and the evolution of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping them to form a plug at the site of bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that platelets and VWF are in a dynamic equilibrium, with the A1 domain of VWF in one state when platelets are not flowing, and in a different state when platelets are flowing. This equilibrium is altered by flow, and by mutations in VWF.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been largely ignored. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and is the first to comprehensively analyze thousands of publicly available metagenomic datasets. We find that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases, and that the virome is a powerful tool for studying human health. This study will allow for the study of the human virome for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This instrument will be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations in the future.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface is in turn controlled by the intensity of solar radiation. The intensity of solar radiation, in turn, is controlled by the composition of the atmosphere. The composition of the atmosphere, in turn, is controlled by the evolution of life. Thus, the evolution of life is intimately linked to the evolution of the atmosphere and the evolution of the atmosphere is intimately linked to the evolution of life. This paper demonstrates that the evolution of life has been intimately linked to the evolution of the atmosphere over geological time. This paper also demonstrates that the evolution of life has been intimately linked to the evolution of the surface temperature of the Earth over geological time. This paper also demonstrates that the evolution of life has been intimately linked to the evolution of the surface temperature of the Earth over geological time.

Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidneys. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is the major potassium channel in the heart. It is normally open and in a closed state during the heart’s repolarization phase. We found that the BK channel’s closed state is state-dependent and that its closing is closed state-dependent. We also found that the BK channel’s closing is slow and that its closing rate is inversely correlated with channel-open probability. These findings provide insights into the BK channel’s normal function and may be useful for the development of BK channel modulators. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the host cell in which it replicates. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, EBA175, to bind to the surface of the RBC and alter its biophysical properties. We show that this interaction leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the RBC and a reduction in its bending modulus. These changes in the RBC are correlated with the ability of the parasite to invade the RBC. This study suggests that the malaria parasite uses a single protein to alter the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our understanding of the invasion process. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for electronic and photonic applications. However, its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under thermal strain. These findings can be used to tailor the electronic properties of diamond. They also provide opportunities for diamond to be used in applications that require both high hardness and high electrical conductivity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While the impact of humidity on viral transmission is well established, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. This article is protected by copyright. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this process is limited. Here, we show that the brain responds to each successive word in a sentence in a similar way, suggesting that the brain applies the same merge operation to all linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. We also show that the brain responds to the merge of words into phrases in a way that is consistent with a parser that applies to the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. They also suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be a fundamental step in the construction of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for the development of the organism. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the brain. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the root microbiome would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable manner. Here, we have developed a system to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the root microbiome of plants. This system is based on the production of a signaling molecule by the plant and the perception of this molecule by the bacteria. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a signaling molecule in this context. This work is a step toward the development of a sustainable agriculture. The Amazon is in the midst of a deforestation crisis. Remote-sensed forest monitoring is a critical tool for monitoring and detecting deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unclear. We study a community-based monitoring program that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. The results from our analysis suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss. However, the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are made up of cellular tissue and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the ears of the orb-weaving spider are not constrained by the organism’s body but are extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is used to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider enables the outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function, which provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. This article is protected by copyright. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 vaccines are needed worldwide to contain the pandemic. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a variant of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein RBD that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity in mice. This variant is well-suited for large-scale microbial production, and we demonstrate that it can be used to generate a virus-like particle vaccine that protects hamsters from viral challenge. This engineered RBD can be used to design vaccines for other pathogens, and we anticipate that it will be useful in the global fight against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is difficult to treat and has a poor prognosis. We show that the ALK protein is mutated in a subset of neuroblastoma. We also show that the ALK protein can be activated by a small secreted protein. This discovery may lead to the development of new therapies for neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of life. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not adapted to the domestication of the flea, and that it rapidly spread across Eurasia. These data also reveal the presence of a flea-adapted form of the pathogen in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for the study of gender, race, and class in the United States. © 2022, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to a massive release of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release. We show that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a systematic approach to identifying and prioritizing the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans. We then used this framework to systematically rank the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery and surveillance efforts. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used to prioritize research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We identify the three enzymatic activities that are necessary for the production of this pigment. We also identify the alkaloid in the red nectar of two other vertebrate-pollinated plants, Jaltomata herrerae, and provide evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait that is essential for the survival of many flowering plants. It also suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the population history of the continent during the period between the migrations of the Celts and the arrival of the Romans is poorly understood. Here we present the genome sequence of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th centuries AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the population history of Europe during the period between the migrations of the Celts and the arrival of the Romans. They also indicate that complex demographic processes may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication. This process is essential for the proper functioning of the human body. The process of DNA replication is carried out by proteins. One of the proteins involved in this process is pol δ. Pol δ is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. It is also responsible for the formation of the holoenzyme.
The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the factors that predict neighborhood improvement in five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other urban systems, such as the dynamics of urban poverty. We hope that our method will be useful to researchers and practitioners in the fields of urban studies, urban informatics, and computer vision.

COVID-19 is a highly fatal disease. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. Tocilizumab, which is approved for rheumatoid arthritis, is a promising treatment for severe COVID-19. In this study, we found that tocilizumab can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also toxic at high concentrations. The ability to control copper levels is therefore critical for the survival of fungi. In this study, we describe the discovery of a family of isocyanide metabolites of the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. These metabolites have significant antimicrobial properties, including inhibition of fungal laccase activity. These findings suggest that the xan BGC isocyanides are important mediators of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings also suggest that the xan BGC isocyanides may be useful as antimicrobial agents. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the crystalline minerals and the mixed-cation salts and oxides, and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific and that these strategies can be used to forecast the future evolution of frost damage. Our findings can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of colitis by two distinct mechanisms. First, they can directly transition to Th1-like cells. Second, they can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of disease and suggest that therapies that target both Th17 cells and their progeny may be more effective than therapies that target Th17 cells alone. This study also highlights the importance of Stat4 and T-bet in the development of Th17 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapies. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of therapies for ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is critical for their health and fitness. However, the ways in which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector hosts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the vector tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the pathogen’s ability to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings reveal the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of vertebrates. The short tail of modern birds is a highly derived feature that is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle). Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with short tails, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it is the earliest known member of the group. We also show that the short tail of birds is a derived feature that evolved multiple times in the lineage leading to modern birds. This study increases our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail. (Show more)

The climate system is very complex, and it is difficult to understand it. However, we can make progress by looking at the simplest parts of the system and then building on that. In this paper, we show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of pigments in the skin. In others, the color is determined by the presence of pigments in the bones. In this study, we show that the presence of pigments in the bones of frogs and toads has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history. We also describe a mechanism that allows the animals to control the color of their bones. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is widespread in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. We show that hypoxia induces breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) in MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells. We also show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which increases NANOG mRNA levels and the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 is a mediator of the BCSC phenotype in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Our findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to target BCSCs in breast cancer. The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. © 2018, The Author(s). The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present the first millennial-scale age model for the extinction and recovery. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization precedes the extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. © 2014, The Author(s).

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific function of RORα is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs.
