The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune response in infected individuals. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.1 Å resolution. We show that the D614G mutation has resulted in a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs. This is a class of games in which the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. Our results extend to a large class of games with tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes. © 2020, The Author(s).

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms. We show that under pressure, the chemical properties of atoms change, and we provide a quantitative description of these changes. We also show that these changes can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena.

Fire is a key natural process in many ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is complex. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been important in shaping the fire regime, and that these have acted to warm the climate in the past. However, we find that recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in shaping the future fire regime. This will be critical for understanding the risks and opportunities of future fire regimes for the climate system.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a luminescent symbiont in a squid–vibrio mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ that is necessary for the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients at specific times of the day may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts. (Read more)

Text data are ubiquitous and have been used to study a wide range of topics. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in many types of text data. We also provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in the fields of text mining, machine learning, criminology, and gender studies.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identity of the rodent reservoir of this disease has been debated for centuries. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were highly correlated, and that these conditions were unfavorable for the survival of the plague vector in Asia. Our results suggest that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are important as prey for many species of fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. They are also a food source for sea stars, which are important predators in their own right. In the past few years, a disease has been observed in sea stars, leading to rapid death. The disease is caused by a virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The disease is associated with a high mutation rate, and the identification of potential therapeutic targets is therefore challenging. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP; IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can be used to treat primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The IL1RAP-targeting antibody described here has the potential to be used in combination with other therapies, such as chemotherapy, to improve the survival rate of AML patients. This antibody could therefore be used as a single agent in the future. Thus, the results presented here provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East, suggesting a recent arrival of Europeans to Madagascar. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the arrival of Europeans was not the only event that shaped the genetic diversity of Madagascar. We also found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the role of the environment in shaping the genetic diversity of human populations. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as T cell receptors and enzymes. Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide critical information on the status of crops, which is used by farmers, policymakers, and the general public. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective. We show that this information can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We also show that this information can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work demonstrates the potential of leveraging the vast network of crop experts to improve the accuracy of agricultural monitoring and forecasting. This work also provides a framework for the use of other types of expert information in agricultural monitoring and forecasting.

Language is a complex system that relies on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Moreover, across all nondesert biomes, respiration rates with and without experimental warming follow a Gaussian response, increasing with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most significant events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it is associated with a complex set of changes in the environment, physiology, and ecology of the organisms involved. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is the primary driver of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This process is likely to have shaped the evolution of the plastid genome and its genes, and may be relevant to other transitions in the evolution of life. This article is protected by copyright. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work can help to inform adaptation efforts. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic quasicrystal, discovered in the Trinity test trinitite, is of particular interest because it is the oldest known example of this class of materials. Here, we report the discovery of this material and its chemical composition.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most important and productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in photosynthesis, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. We show that the diiron protein is the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of the enzyme in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes play a critical role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings also suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of EAE and suggest a potential therapeutic target for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest period in the state’s recorded history. We show that the drought is more likely to occur when conditions are warm. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that human-caused climate warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that forgetting is a common mechanism for autism-risk genes. This study also provides a powerful tool for studying the function of autism-risk genes in the fruit fly. This study will be useful for understanding the molecular mechanisms of autism and for developing new therapeutic strategies.

This work is the first to our knowledge to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the public. It also provides the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in this regard. The results suggest that the prevalence of negativity biases is likely to be higher than previously thought, and that there is reason to question the conventional wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in Stormorken syndrome. We show that p.R304W in STIM1 is a gain-of-function mutation that causes spontaneous bleeding and thrombocytopenia in zebrafish embryos. We also show that p.P245L in ORAI1 is a constitutively active gain-of-function mutation. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome. (Read more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell autonomous and that aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) H1N1 infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit both SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also show that one of the compounds is uniquely effective in a panel of B-cell cancers, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency in B-cell cancers. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT that could be used to treat cancer. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in multiple genes, and the pathology of the disease is characterized by the formation of intracellular inclusions. These inclusions contain a variety of proteins that are not normally found in the same cellular compartment. We show that the proteins that are found in these inclusions are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. Thus, the proteins that are found in inclusions are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that the formation of inclusions in ALS is a consequence of the metastable nature of the proteins that are found in these inclusions. This metastable nature of the inclusions may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, enabling the study of many-body physics in a wide range of systems. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant that lived in the Cretaceous. Montsechia is an important fossil because it is the oldest known flowering plant with flowers.

Parvoviruses are small, circular, double-stranded DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are known to cause a number of diseases, including fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from the present day, but the evolution of parvoviruses in the past has been difficult to study. Here we present the first evidence for the evolution of parvoviruses in the past. We find that the evolution of parvoviruses is much slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising on a global scale. This is a well-known fact. However, the rate of rise is not constant. In fact, it is changing. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of change of sea level.

Pain is a major public health problem. It is also a complex phenomenon, with many causes and many dimensions. This paper focuses on one aspect of pain: its distribution across the life course. It finds that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort. This increase is not seen for those with a bachelor’s degree. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the chemical dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. From this analysis, we understand the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state and the fate of the leaving group. We also show that the isostere indole is unable to react with the intermediate, highlighting the importance of the three-dimensional structure for understanding reaction mechanisms. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high mortality rate. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. Remdesivir, an antiviral drug used to treat Ebola virus disease, has shown promising results in vitro and in animal models. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection, and may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study supports the need for further clinical development of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS and other coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that the sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is critical for infection of human lung-derived cells. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These results also suggest that the first cleavages may be a promising target for antiviral therapy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of sequential proteolysis in virus–cell membrane fusion. It also provides a rationale for the development of antiviral therapies. This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This has the potential to contribute to the global effort to reduce the environmental and health impacts of meat consumption. The study also provides evidence that this approach can be effective in the real world, without the need for complex interventions or costly behavioral change campaigns. The approach could be extended to other types of food service, such as hospitals and schools. The approach could also be extended to other types of food service, such as hospitals and schools.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a panel of six of the most prominent oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step forward in understanding the cancer cell surfaceome.

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs to electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, and the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 provides a molecular basis for the unique immune evasion and spread activities of SARS-CoV-2. These activities may be mediated by the unique dimerization interface. The structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 provides a foundation for future studies of the role of this protein in the pandemic. Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also provide a new perspective for the treatment of cerebral edema in other conditions, such as brain trauma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important. Unfortunately, it is very difficult to decide which associations are important. We describe a method for making this decision.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that are required for the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs is still unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous forkhead box C2 (FOXC2), ETV2 induces expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of vascular networks in regenerative medicine. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. We have identified two physiological ligands for Alk and Ltk, which are encoded by two additional genes in the human genome. We show that these ligands are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. We also show that these ligands are important for the development of iridophores, a unique type of photoreceptor that is found in the eyes of many vertebrates. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of Alk and Ltk in the context of their physiological ligands. It also provides a model system for studying the function of Alk and Ltk in the context of their physiological ligands. This work may also have implications for the development of therapeutics for cancer and pigmentation disorders.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Specifically, STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual occurrence of influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is sequence dependent and might be involved in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings have important implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly localized process, which suggests that the local hemodynamic environment plays an important role in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms by which the local hemodynamic environment regulates the development of atherosclerotic lesions are not well understood. In this study, we identified a critical role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. These findings may also provide insights into the development of new therapeutic strategies for atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the factors that predict neighborhood improvement in five US cities. We find that three factors are important: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results provide a new way to study the physical dynamics of cities. They also have implications for urban planning and policy.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Zika virus (ZIKV) has spread rapidly across the Americas, causing a public health emergency. The virus has been associated with microcephaly and other neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the observed dynamics of the virus in the primate. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of the virus. We use the model to predict that favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, can reduce the time to clearance of the virus by ∼2 d. This study can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. We also show that the tumors activate a JNK-dependent feedback loop that triggers a regenerative response in the microbiome. This in turn leads to a loss of the intestinal barrier and the development of tumors. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. This work has implications for the understanding of the role of the microbiome in cancer and for the development of therapies to treat intestinal tumors. This article is protected by copyright. Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer. However, the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients do not respond to treatment. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Furthermore, we found that ROR1 expression was associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reestablish tumors in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. However, this attribution is based on a single proxy record, and the timing and nature of the climate changes are debated. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series, coincident with the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong climate response. This provides a plausible explanation for the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation and the associated climate changes.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. Our data can be used to identify regions where freshwater fisheries are most productive and where they are most threatened by degradation. This information can be used to prioritize conservation efforts and to improve the sustainability of fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is mainly determined by the negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve high-energy and durable aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which the genetic material of a species is mixed up. It is essential for the production of offspring, and it is the basis for the development of new species. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the function of the brain. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the resting brain can be used to identify and validate the main resting state networks. We also show that this organization is altered in disease. This approach can be used to identify the functional significance of the changes in the brain organization.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of messenger RNA (mRNA). We show that a second cap structure is found on subsets of mRNA, and that this cap is not the cap of tRNA or rRNA. This cap is found on mitochondrial mRNAs, and is not found on nuclear mRNAs. We propose that this cap structure is important for the function of the mRNA.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) demonstrated that intensive therapy could prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist over time in people with diabetes and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the persistence of DNA-me alterations over time. These findings may help to explain the long-term benefits of intensive therapy and may lead to new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness. This is a new finding in the field of alcohol dependence, which suggests that the gut barrier may be involved in the development of the disease. Moreover, we found that gut leakiness is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of detoxification. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies. © 2016, American Psychological Association. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. Many of these chemicals are nitrogenous, meaning that they contain nitrogen. The biosynthetic pathways for many of these nitrogenous volatiles are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the identification of a pathway for the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for the improvement of tomato flavor. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the map of local space, are strongly coupled to each other, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells tend to intermingle. These data suggest that grid cells might be largely distinct from those of other cell types and that grid cells exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. Our results have implications for understanding the organization of the MEC map of local space. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to move from the host to the parasite and interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to induce flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in the striatum form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides insights into the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system and its potential role in health and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others. We show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust signal of connection. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connection with them. This signal is also used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of our connection with others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs). SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand by integrating the membrane and store-operated Ca2+ clocks. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Our study reveals a previously unknown role of STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. This study also provides insights into the mechanism of SAN dysfunction in heart failure. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has been debated. Here, we show that Si can enhance resistance against insect herbivores by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si can promote the accumulation of Si in plants, which in turn can enhance the activity of the JA signaling pathway and the production of the herbivore-induced JA precursor alle-O-ene. These results provide insights into the mechanism by which Si can enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results demonstrate that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is essential for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that relies on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biomanufacturing. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNAs to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of plant-based biomanufacturing. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution from small tributaries is a growing concern for the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, our understanding of the relative importance of small tributaries is limited by the lack of comprehensive data. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries are disproportionately important in terms of the nutrient loads they deliver. This finding suggests that small watersheds may be a significant source of coastal nutrient pollution. Our results highlight the need to expand monitoring and management efforts to small tributaries to protect the health of nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a mechanical system driven by a random force. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. We show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis can cause changes in the dynamics of the brain, which can be explained by a simple model of the brain. We then show that these changes in brain dynamics can be used to predict the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients. These findings have implications for the development of new therapies for this disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event. To understand the causes of this warming, it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming events in the past. Here, we present evidence for an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming was caused by a global-scale anoxia that led to a release of organic matter–derived carbon.

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been evaluated in a systematic way. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet achieving its potential to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is essential for the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a major area of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In others, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we show that the latter scenario can produce a modular pattern of secondary sexual characteristics, where the same genetic sex can produce different phenotypes. This modularity can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-generated photoproducts of lipids. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in the retina, promote the oxidation and degradation of a class of lipid photoproducts, the retinal pigment lipofuscin. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the levels of iron in the retina can be targeted to protect the retina from oxidative damage. This strategy could be extended to other tissues that are challenged by oxidative damage. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs. However, the evolution of specialization in predators is often considered a dead end. We show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a stepping stone to morphological diversification and diversification of prey types. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization in predators is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations. These findings contribute to understanding the evolution of predators and their role in food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human biology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit both SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also show that one of the compounds is uniquely effective in a panel of B-cell cancers, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency in B-cell cancers. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT that could be used to treat cancer. This work also provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT that could be used to treat cancer.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the resulting loss of natural habitats is a major threat to biodiversity. However, little is known about the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the increase in subsoil compaction risk has been a major driver of the evolution of sauropods, the largest terrestrial animals that ever walked the Earth. Our findings have important implications for the design of farm machinery and the evolution of sauropods. They also suggest that the increase in subsoil compaction risk may have been a major driver of the extinction of the dinosaurs. © 2019, The Author(s).
